tt_insn_vec.help: Portion of vector registers that is actually used. Available only for instructions belonging to a SIMD/vector instructions set (like x86 AVX)

tt_Recip_throughput.help: Average number of cycles to retire that instruction if repeated (assuming independent instructions, with no read-after-write dependency)

hint.workaround:
Pass to your compiler a micro-architecture specialization option:
 - Please look into your compiler manual for march=native or equivalent
hint.details:
These instructions generate more than one micro-operation and only one of them can be decoded during a cycle and the extra micro-operations increase pressure on execution units.
 - CVTSI2SD: 2 occurrences<<list_path_1_complex_1>>
 - CVTTSD2SI: 2 occurrences<<list_path_1_complex_2>>
hint.title: Complex instructions

hint.workaround: Avoid mixing data with different types. In particular, check if the type of constants is the same as array elements.
hint.details:
- CVTSI2SD (INT32/64 to FP64, scalar): 2 occurrences<<list_path_1_cvt_1>>
 - CVTTSD2SI (FP64 to INT32/64, scalar): 2 occurrences<<list_path_1_cvt_2>>
hint.title: Conversion instructions
Type of elements and instruction set
hint.txt: 1 SSE or AVX instructions are processing arithmetic or math operations on double precision FP elements in scalar mode (one at a time).

hint.title: Matching between your function (in the source code) and the binary function
hint.txt:
The binary function is composed of 1 FP arithmetical operations:
 - 1: multiply
The binary function is loading 36 bytes (4 double precision FP elements).
The binary function is storing 24 bytes (3 double precision FP elements).

hint.title: Arithmetic intensity
hint.txt: Arithmetic intensity is 0.02 FP operations per loaded or stored byte.

expert.help: Front-end corresponds to instructions fetching and decoding into macro/micro operations
expert.title: Front-end
expert.txt:
MACRO FUSION NOT POSSIBLE
FIT IN UOP CACHE
micro-operation queue: 5.67 cycles
front end            : 5.67 cycles

expert.help: Back-end corresponds to macro/micro operations execution (includes allocating registers, fetching operands etc.)
expert.title: Back-end
expert.txt:
| ALU0/BRU0 | ALU1 | ALU2 | ALU3 | BRU1 | AGU0 | AGU1 | AGU2 | FP0  | FP1  | FP2  | FP3  | FP4  | FP5
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
uops   | 3.75      | 3.75 | 3.75 | 3.75 | 3.00 | 2.67 | 2.67 | 2.67 | 0.50 | 0.50 | 2.00 | 2.00 | 2.50 | 2.50
cycles | 3.75      | 3.75 | 3.75 | 3.75 | 3.00 | 2.67 | 2.67 | 2.67 | 0.50 | 0.50 | 2.00 | 2.00 | 2.50 | 2.50

Execution ports to units layout:
 - ALU0/BRU0: ALU, BRU
 - ALU1: ALU
 - ALU2: ALU
 - ALU3: ALU
 - BRU1: BRU
 - AGU0 (256 bits): store address, load
 - AGU1 (256 bits): store address, load
 - AGU2 (256 bits): store address, load
 - FP0 (256 bits): VPU, DIV/SQRT
 - FP1 (256 bits): VPU, DIV/SQRT
 - FP2 (256 bits): VPU
 - FP3 (256 bits): VPU
 - FP4 (256 bits): FP store data
 - FP5 (256 bits): FP store data

Cycles executing div or sqrt instructions: NA

expert.help: Compare the CQA-computed load/store/compute metrics with the capacity of the core. For instance if CQA computes 24 bytes in the loop in 2 cycles (that is 12 cycles per cycle) and if the core can process up to 16 bytes per cycle, that metric is 75%.
expert.title: Cycles and memory resources usage
expert.txt:
Assuming all data fit into the L1 cache, each call to the function takes 5.67 cycles. At this rate:
 - 6% of peak load performance is reached (6.35 out of 96.00 bytes loaded per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))
 - 6% of peak store performance is reached (4.24 out of 64.00 bytes stored per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))

expert.title: Front-end bottlenecks
expert.txt:
Performance is limited by instruction throughput (loading/decoding program instructions to execution core) (front-end is a bottleneck).

By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 5.67 to 3.75 cycles (1.51x speedup).

header:
Warnings:
The number of fused uops of the instruction [INT	$0x3] is unknown
0% of peak computational performance is used (0.18 out of 24.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
- Try to reorganize arrays of structures to structures of arrays
 - Consider to permute loops (see vectorization gain report)
 - To reference allocatable arrays, use "allocatable" instead of "pointer" pointers or qualify them with the "contiguous" attribute (Fortran 2008)
 - For structures, limit to one indirection. For example, use a_b%c instead of a%b%c with a_b set to a%b before this function
gain.title: Code clean check
gain.txt:
Detected a slowdown caused by scalar integer instructions (typically used for address computation).
By removing them, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 5.67 to 3.17 cycles (1.79x speedup).

gain.workaround:
- Try another compiler or update/tune your current one
 - Make array accesses unit-stride:
  * If your function streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA):
do i a(i)%x = b(i)%x (slow, non stride 1) => do i a%x(i) = b%x(i) (fast, stride 1)
gain.details:
Store and arithmetical SSE/AVX instructions are used in scalar version (process only one data element in vector registers).
Since your execution units are vector units, only a vectorized function can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your function is probably not vectorized.
Only 12% of vector register length is used (average across all SSE/AVX instructions).
By vectorizing your function, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 5.67 to 0.50 cycles (11.33x speedup).

gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt: Found no such bottlenecks but see expert reports for more complex bottlenecks.
